In the paragraph, the author suggests that the association of the tumor with preexisting hydroureteronephrosis (a condition characterized by the accumulation of urine in the kidney) suggests that the stasis (prolonged and intensified exposure) of the upper urinary tract epithelium to cyclophosphamide (a chemotherapy drug) may have played a role in the development of the tumor.
